info.title: Configure virtual disk cache mode using &virsh;

abstract.para: A virtual disk is an essential part of a virtual machine (VM). To speed up disk reading and writing operations, you can enable a caching mechanism. This article describes how to configure a virtual disk cache mode using the command-line tool &virsh;.

step.para: Open your favorite terminal application and identify the VM.
step.screen: &prompt.sudo;virsh list --all Id Name State --------------------------- - sle15sp5 shut off

step.para: Identify the disk for which you want to configure the cache mode.
step.screen: &prompt.sudo;virsh domblklist sle15sp5 Target Source ------------------------------------------ vda /home/tbazant/virt/sle15.qcow2 sda -

step.para: Dump the XML definition of the VM to a file.
Edit the dumped XML file and search for a <disk/> definition that includes a path to your disk in the <source>definition, for example:
step.screen: <disk type='file' device='disk'> <driver name='qemu' type='qcow2' cache='writethrough'/> <source file='/home/tbazant/virt/sle15.qcow2'/> <target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/> <address type='pci' domain='0x0000' bus='0x04' slot='0x00' function='0x0'/> </disk>

step.para: Update the <driver/> definition and append cache='CACHE_TYPE'. Replace CACHE_TYPE with one of the caching modes described in . For example:
Save the updated XML definition and update the VM accordingly, for example:
step.screen: &prompt.sudo;sudo virsh define virt/sle15sp5.xml Domain 'sle15sp5' defined from virt/sle15sp5.xml

note.para: You may have to restart a running VM for the changes to take effect.
